timeline.bodyText: Why can't we reuse the preferredLocale? Would it make any sense for users to set locale to X and documentation to Y?
timeline.author: hustodemon
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -505,6 +505,18 @@
      */
     void setPreferredLocale(String locale);
 
+    /**
+     * Returns the user's preferred documentation locale
+     * @return String docsLocale
+     */
+    String getPreferredDocsLocale();

replies.bodyText: That was one of the requests Pau had. That they can be set individually. (The set of languages do not necessarily match). See the issue linked
replies.author: parlt91

replies.bodyText: Ok, thanks for explaining. That's resolved for me.
replies.author: hustodemon

timeline.bodyText: Please use type args for the involved variables/return value.
timeline.author: hustodemon

replies.bodyText: Extracting the common code with buildImageMap would be nice: these methods do the same thing, the only difference is the list of locales, which could be passed as an arg.
replies.author: hustodemon

timeline.bodyText: Nit: similarly, we could write a method here that would do the concatenation, which would slightly improve the readability. No big deal though.
timeline.author: hustodemon

replies.bodyText: The new version is even nicer, than what I got in mind. Thanks!
replies.author: hustodemon

timeline.bodyText:
Just a suggestion for improvement: Alternatively to the approach in this commit ("Localize jade file documentation links"), we could think of the following alteratives:

instead of withUser, create withDocsLocale helper, that would inject the locale to the model (data.put("docsLocale"... could be skipped in the individual handlers
or we could inject the docsLocale into the shared variables (SparkApplicationHelper), but I think this would be a bit more complicated (we couldn't inject just the value, since the setup method is only called once. instead of that, we would need to inject a method for computing that stuff). so maybe not :)

Using one of these would get rid of manual filling of the docsLocale model parameter. I'm up for a discussion about this!
timeline.author: hustodemon

replies.bodyText:
There is only one concern I have with this approach. When writing a controller method that has a jade file that uses docsLocale, you would have to add the user (to get the users docsLocale) to the method signature although the method itself might not need to use the user. This is somewhat counter intuitive.
But I agree, that it would make the code cleaner. So no strong opinion against it.
replies.author: parlt91

replies.bodyText: Actually forget my last comment. It worked out differently than I thought it would. I didn't need to add the user to the methods signatures. Just check out the result and resolve if you're satisfied.
replies.author: parlt91

timeline.bodyText: Maybe using Optionals you could get rid of this if/else condition and do everything in one line. Just an improvement suggestion though.
timeline.author: ncounter

replies.bodyText:
I used a different approach since I couldn't fit the optional thing in one line: using ifPresentOrElse().
Just have another look
replies.author: parlt91

timeline.bodyText:
Wow, the logic here is a bit tricky:
if A is not null and it is equals to something, then you set the initial A to null
Why not  just comparing default string to the possible null one instead? Something like "default".equals(preferredDocsLocale) should not throw errors in case it is null and you can handle everything in one line then. Something like user.setPreferredDocsLocale("default".equals(preferredDocsLocale) ? null : preferredDocsLocale), or even better using Optionals while fetching the form.getString("preferredDocsLocale"). I'm just suggesting though.
timeline.author: ncounter

replies.bodyText: I like your first option. It's really short. But IMO it is much harder to understand whats going on than using the if(...) syntax. Still going for your proposal (I like cryptic code after all 😄)
replies.author: parlt91
